Comments_List: Conceptual knowledge about different styles of fossil preservation, their drivers, and their distribution through space and time.

I have never thought about paleontology from a taphonomic standpoint, and I feel like I learned something new and insightful every single class. I've learned so much more about the chemical and geologic impacts on fossils. Aside from the class lectures, I also had the opportunity to develop my own research project, which allowed me to further my writing/research abilities, as well as learn about taphonomy with a more focused and in-depth view focused on a limited number of specimens.
I gained research skills in new methods and analytical techniques. I gained practice in scientific writing and experience in presentation.

- Taphonomy basics
- Routes of preservation for fossils, biomolecules, and soft tissue
- How to do taphonomy and paleontology research
- The layout of the VP prep lab complex
- Vertebrate digestive physiology
- Lab methods: SEM, EDX, XRD (overview), specimen photography, Raman.

Strengths: Flexibility. You could tailor the course to your specific interests. Derek is a compelling lecturer, and I was gripped by the content during every session.
Improvement: Perhaps the opportunity for grad/undergrad students to pair up for projects? Or group projects in general.

I think this class is very well put together. We receive a number of lectures from Dr. Briggs as well as other invited speakers which gives us the opportunity to hear from other experts and points of view. Specimens were brought to every lecture to give us a physical example of what we were learning about that day. I have no suggestions to improve the course.

- Weaknesses: None. 
Our class was too quiet as a whole, but I'm not sure how that could have been changed.

- Strengths: 
(1) Derek's lecturing, with strong supplementary lectures by Lidya, Susan, Jasmina, Luke, and others. 
(2) Single (2-part) assessment in form of class project and presentation. This let us delve deeply into a particular problem of taphonomy.
Yes. It is a great review of the history of taphonomy, as well as current knowledge of the field.
Yes. If you are at all interested in paleontology and the history of life, I think it is important to understand the impacts that fossilization and the passage of time can have on the specimens.
Absolutely, the course material is interesting and we'll presented. And the class project is a great opportunity to explore new research ideas.

Absolutely! Without question: take it!
I knew nothing about taphonomy before taking this class, and now I feel comfortable with all of its basic principles, and capable of combing the literature to learn any particulars I might need.
